content.webTitle: Martin Luther King: how a Bible and Nobel medal have split his family

fields.headline: Martin Luther King: how a Bible and Nobel medal have split his family
fields.bodyText: With an Oscar-contender film about him in theaters and a national holiday in his honor on the horizon, Martin Luther King Jr would seem to have upheld one of the most secure American legacies of personal commitment to a greater cause. But the battle over King’s legacy threatened to turn into a “business issue” in an Atlanta courtroom Tuesday, where a judge heard arguments in a case pitting the civil rights leader’s two sons against his sole surviving daughter. At stake was the fate of two King artifacts too significant to be called memorabilia: the Bible he traveled with as a young man, and the Nobel Peace Prize he was awarded in 1964. King’s sons, Martin Luther King III and Dexter Scott King, had asked the court to force their sister, Bernice King, to turn the objects over to the King estate they control, for possible sale. Fulton County superior court judge Robert McBurney declined to rule in the case Tuesday, saying he hoped to do so before a trial date scheduled for February, when the longstanding episode in a family drama over the King estate could finally come to a close. Dexter King declined to tell reporters outside the court Tuesday whether the objects would be put up for sale if the brothers win the case. “This is a business issue, and it’s certainly my hope that we can resolve it ultimately in some type of form that precludes having to go to trial,” he told the Charlotte Observer. “But if we can’t, that’s why courts are here.” The medal and Bible currently are being held by the court. Lawyers for Bernice King argued at the hearing that the objects were more important to the King legacy than previously sold objects and documents. The episode laid bare yet again tensions among the siblings, who have disagreed in court for years about the management of the King legacy. Last year Bernice King said in a court statement that her father “MUST be turning in his grave” at the latest proposed sale. “While I love my brothers dearly, this latest decision by them is extremely troubling,” Bernice King said. “Not only am I appalled and utterly ashamed, I am frankly disappointed that they would even entertain the thought of selling these precious items. It reveals a desperation beyond comprehension.” The brothers have argued that the estate, in which Bernice has a one-third voting share, needs money for its educational mission and to maintain King’s legacy. The King estate has a history of asserting ownership in court of the civil rights icon’s most famous works and words. In 1999, the family fought CBS News over unpaid royalties for the network airing King’s “I have a dream” speech. In 2008, the estate criticized Harry Belafonte, the singer and friend of King, for plans to auction King documents. Belafonte won a lawsuit against the estate to retain possession of the documents. According to appraisers interviewed by the Associated Press, the Nobel medal could sell for $5-$10m or more and the Bible could bring anywhere from $200,000 to $1m. A sale of King documents by the family in 2006 brought $32m. King’s wife, Coretta Scott King, died in 2006 and King’s first daughter, Yolanda King, died in 2007. The media arm of the Nobel Prize tweeted about the dispute on Tuesday, but did not return a call and email seeking comment on the case. President Barack Obama swore on the King Bible for his second inauguration, which fell on Martin Luther King Jr Day in 2013, the 50th anniversary of the “I have a dream” speech. The Bible is a King James. King’s Nobel acceptance speech extolled the principle of nonviolence. “After contemplation, I conclude that this award which I receive on behalf of that movement is a profound recognition that nonviolence is the answer to the crucial political and moral question of our time – the need for man to overcome oppression and violence without resorting to violence and oppression,” King said. “Civilization and violence are antithetical concepts.” Born in Atlanta in 1929, King earned a divinity degree and became a pastor in Alabama at age 25. He preached at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta and was a founder of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, a consortium of southern black churches that was a key organizing force behind the 1963 March on Washington, the Selma voting rights movement and other watershed moments of the civil rights era. King was assassinated in Memphis on 4 April, 1968. King’s birthday is Thursday. Martin Luther King Jr Day is this coming Monday. Selma is considered a Best Picture lock when the Academy Award nominations are released on Thursday.
